revisions.rev:
{{Infobox musical artist | name = Trick Daddy | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Maurice Young | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1973|9|27}} | origin = [[Miami, Florida]], [[United States]] | genre = [[Hip Hop]], [[Southern Rap]], [[Crunk]] | occupation = [[Rapper]], [[Record producer|Producer]], [[Songwriter]], [[Actor]] | years_active = 1994âpresent | label = [[Slip-n-Slide Records]], [[Warlock Records]], Trick Daddy Music Group | associated_acts = [[Gorilla Tek]], [[Scarface (rapper)|Scarface]], [[Luther Campbell]], [[Ying Yang Twins]], [[Bigg D]], [[Diplo (DJ)|Diplo]], [[DJ Khaled]], [[Brisco]], [[Young Buck]] | website = [http://www.trickdaddy.com www.trickdaddy.com] }} ''' Maurice Young''' (born September 27, 1973), better known by his stage name '''Trick Daddy''', is a certified platinum American [[rapper]] and [[Record producer|producer]] from Miami, Florida.
==Music career== Trick appeared on the track "Scarred" by former [[2 Live Crew]] member, [[Luther Campbell|Luther "Luke" Campbell]], Produced by Darren "DJ Spin" Rudnick, from Luke's 1996 album ''[[Uncle Luke]]''. The song became a hit and immediately caught the attention of fans and record producers alike. Ted Lucas, a former concert promoter and then-CEO of Slip-n-Slide Records, signed the rapper to the newly formed record label. Slip-n-Slide released Trick Daddy Dollars's debut album ''[[Based on a True Story (Trick Daddy album)|Based on a True Story]]'' in 1997; the album was popular in the Miami area.<ref name="allmusic">{{cite web|last=Birchmeier|first=Jason|title=Trick Daddy > Biography|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p413655|pure_url=yes}}|publisher=allmusic|date=2006-12-19|accessdate=2008-09-11}}</ref>
In 1998, when his next album ''[[www.thug.com]]'' came out, Trick removed "Dollars" from his stage name. Club-oriented track "[[Nann Nigga]]", featuring [[Trina]], became a national hit, peaking at the third spot of the ''Billboard'' Hot Rap Singles chart.<ref name="Singles charts">{{cite web|title=Trick Daddy - Billboard Singles|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p413655|pure_url=yes}}|publisher=allmusic|accessdate=2008-09-11}}</ref> [[Atlantic Records]] signed Trick Daddy to the label in 2000 and released ''[[Book of Thugs|Book of Thugs: Chapter AK Verse 47]]'' that year. "Shut Up", which Jason Birchmeier of [[allmusic]] considered "a rowdy club hit similar to 'Nann Nigga'",<ref name="allmusic"/> followed "Nann" as the next single; featured guests on "Shut Up" were Deuce Poppito, Trina, and Co.
''[[Thugs Are Us]]'', released in 2001, featured the hit single "I'm a Thug", which reached #17 on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100.<ref name="Singles charts"/> His fifth album ''[[Thug Holiday]]'' boasted "In da Wind", which Birchmeier believed was Trick Daddy's most creative single.<ref name="allmusic"/> In 2004, ''[[Thug Matrimony: Married To The Streets]]'' was released, with hit single "[[Let's Go (Trick Daddy song)|Let's Go]]", produced by [[Lil Jon]], featuring [[Twista]], and sampling the guitar riffs from the [[Ozzy Osbourne]] hit "[[Crazy Train]]".<ref name="allmusic"/> That year, Trick Daddy guest-performed on the [[Ying Yang Twins]]' "What's Happnin!", which reached #30 on the Hot 100, #7 on the Rhythmic Top 40, and #9 on the Hot Rap Singles.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ying Yang Twins - Billboard Singles|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p392373|pure_url=yes}}|publisher=allmusic|accessdate=2008-09-11}}</ref> "Let's Go" peaked on #7 on the Hot 100, #4 on the Rhythmic Top 40, and #4 on Hot Rap Tracks.<ref name="Singles charts"/> ''[[Back By Thug Demand]]'' followed in 2006,<ref name="allmusic"/> with singles "Bet That" and "Tuck Ya Ice" charting at the bottom of the Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Singles & Tracks chart.<ref name="Singles charts"/>
Following ''Back By Thug Demand'', Trick Daddy appeared on several singles by [[DJ Khaled]]: "Born-N-Raised" in 2006 from ''[[Listennn... the Album]]'' in 2006, "[[I'm So Hood]]" from ''[[We the Best]]'', and "Out Here Grindin'" from ''[[We Global]]'' in 2008, all among numerous other rappers. "Born-N-Raised" peaked at #83 on the Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Singles, and "I'm So Hood" peaked at #19 on the Hot 100 and #5 on the Hot Rap Tracks.<ref>{{cite web|title=DJ Khaled - Billboard Singles|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p672134|pure_url=yes}} |publisher=allmusic|accessdate=2008-09-11}}</ref> He appeared on [[Pitbull (rapper)|Pitbull]]'s 2007 album ''[[The Boatlift]]''.<ref>{{cite news|last=Rodriguez|first=Jayson|title=Lil Jon, Trick Daddy Among Boatload Of Guests On Pitbull's Boatlift|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1558115/20070426/pitbull_2_.jhtml|publisher=MTV News|date=2007-04-27|accessdate=2008-09-11}}</ref> Trick Daddy left Slip-n-Slide in 2008 and released his 8th studio album ''Finally Famous: Born a Thug Die a Thug'' on September 25, 2009, under his own Dunk Ryder Records. In late 2010 Trick Daddy formed a new label Trick Daddy Music Group, signing fellow rappers Kasino, A-Dot, Dutch Dirty and 2T to the roster. Trick Daddy is currently working on a new album to be released in 2012 under his new label. Recently he has released a single featuring [[Young Jeezy]], called "I Can't Leave These Streets Alone", a very deep and much felt track from both the rappers, that talks about street life and their growth as men in it.
==Film career== In 2009 Trick Daddy appeared in the film ''Just Another Day'' playing Roman, a shifty and horny drug dealer. The film is about the intersecting lives of an aspiring rapper and an old successful rapper over the course of one day. {{Citation needed|date=April 2011}}
==Personal life== Trick Daddy announced that he has [[lupus erythematosus|lupus]], which has affected his skin, and that he has stopped taking medication to combat the disease.<ref name="Trick Daddy Refuses Treatment For Lupus ">{{cite web|last=Arnold|first=Paul|title=Trick Daddy Refuses Treatment For Lupus|url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.8832/title.trick-daddy-refuses-treatment-for-lupus|work=HipHopDX|date=2009-03-30|accessdate=2009-03-30}}</ref> The rapper's rationale for refusing treatment was that "Because for every medicine they gave me I had to take a test or another medicine every thirty days or so to make sure that medicine wasnât causing side effects dealing with kidney or liver failureâ¦I just said all together I ainât taking no medicine."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.idiomag.com/peek/73059/trick_daddy|title=Trick Daddy Refuses Treatment For Lupus|accessdate=2009-04-01|date=2009-03-31|publisher=[[idiomag]]}}</ref>
==Discography== {{Main|Trick Daddy discography}}<!-- This section within article is for studio albums only. --> *1997: ''[[Based on a True Story (Trick Daddy album)|Based on a True Story]]'' *1998: ''[[www.thug.com]]'' *2000: ''[[Book of Thugs|Book of Thugs: Chapter AK Verse 47]]'' *2001: ''[[Thugs Are Us]]'' *2002: ''[[Thug Holiday]]'' *2004: ''[[Thug Matrimony: Married to the Streets]]'' *2006: ''[[Back by Thug Demand]]'' *2009: ''[[Finally Famous: Born a Thug, Still a Thug]]'' *TBA: ''www.thug.com2''<ref>[http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.12098/title.dx-news-bits-lloyd-banks-ruff-ryders-and-trick-daddy DX News Bits: Lloyd Banks, Ruff Ryders and Trick Daddy]</ref>
